assigmentName: WEEK 6 AEB PREPARATION: Reflective Writing: Theory

value: What would I do differently in future?

possible_responses: What would I do differently in future?
data.stimulus:
TASK 1: Structuring Reflective Writing - Review

Below are the three stages of reflective writing, and the questions you need to answer in each stage. Drag the questions to match the appropriate stage.

value: What would I do differently in future?

When we began our project, tasks were shared out equally amongst members of my team. However, the tasks were not seen as equally difficult by all team members. As a result, the sense of unfairness made it challenging for us to work together as a team.

Social interdependence theory recognises a type of group interaction called “positive interdependence” (Johnson & Johnson, 2008), which we did not experience in my group. This put my group at a disadvantage, as many studies show that cooperative learning experiences encourage higher achievement.” (Maughan & Webb, 2010)

In the end, we managed to complete our project through further negotiation, but to improve the process, we perhaps needed a team leader to help encourage discussion and cooperation when tasks are being shared out. In future group work I would probably suggest this at the beginning of the project.

possible_responses: Social interdependence theory recognises a type of group interaction called “positive interdependence” (Johnson & Johnson, 2008), which we did not experience in my group. This put my group at a disadvantage, as many studies show that cooperative learning experiences encourage higher achievement.” (Maughan & Webb, 2010)

In the end, we managed to complete our project through further negotiation, but to improve the process, we perhaps needed a team leader to help encourage discussion and cooperation when tasks are being shared out. In future group work I would probably suggest this at the beginning of the project.

When we began our project, tasks were shared out equally amongst members of my team. However, the tasks were not seen as equally difficult by all team members. As a result, the sense of unfairness made it challenging for us to work together as a team.
data.stimulus:
TASK 2: Structuring Reflective Writing: an example

Organise the pieces of reflective writing below according to the structure.

value: When we began our project, tasks were shared out equally amongst members of my team. However, the tasks were not seen as equally difficult by all team members. As a result, the sense of unfairness made it challenging for us to work together as a team.

Social interdependence theory recognises a type of group interaction called “positive interdependence” (Johnson & Johnson, 2008), which we did not experience in my group. This put my group at a disadvantage, as many studies show that cooperative learning experiences encourage higher achievement.” (Maughan & Webb, 2010)

In the end, we managed to complete our project through further negotiation, but to improve the process, we perhaps needed a team leader to help encourage discussion and cooperation when tasks are being shared out. In future group work I would probably suggest this at the beginning of the project.

stems: Has the author described what happened and how they felt?
Has the author analysed the situation and considered why things happened?
Has the author used theory to help them understand their experience?
Has the author used personal language (e.g. I, my) to help them reflect on their experience?
Has the author written in a suitably formal academic style?
Has the author checked their writing for errors (e.g. spelling, punctuation, grammar)?
data.stimulus:
TASK 3: Evaluation

Read the reflective writing again and answer the questions in the checklist below.

options.label: Ellis (2012) argues that allocating tasks effectively can offer significant time savings when working in a group.
Largo & Johns (2008) state that ensuring close matches between project roles and real-life personality traits are more likely to produce positive results.
Atkins & Lowe (2011, p.19) argue that a successful team needs "commitment from each team contributor to be a key agent of change".

data.stimulus: ISSUE ONE: Reflecting upon my role as 'key negotiator', I felt at the time that this did not entirely suit my personality profile.

options.label: Ellis (2012) argues that allocating tasks effectively can offer significant time savings when working in a group.
Largo & Johns (2008) state that ensuring close matches between project roles and real-life personality traits are more likely to produce positive results.
Atkins & Lowe (2011, p.19) argue that a successful team needs "commitment from each team contributor to be a key agent of change".

data.stimulus: ISSUE TWO: Effectively allocating tasks and meeting deadlines were two issues we faced. It was often hard to allocate tasks to team members, due to conflicting schedules, workloads and other commitments.

options.label: Ellis (2012) argues that allocating tasks effectively can offer significant time savings when working in a group.
Largo & Johns (2008) state that ensuring close matches between project roles and real-life personality traits are more likely to produce positive results.
Atkins & Lowe (2011, p.19) argue that a successful team needs "commitment from each team contributor to be a key agent of change".

data.stimulus: ISSUE THREE: We had disputes with individuals not arriving to scheduled meetings on time and failing to undertake activities in a timely manner.

list: Largo & Johns (2008) state that ensuring close matches between project roles and real-life personality traits are more likely to produce positive results.
Reflecting upon my role as ‘key negotiator’, I felt at the time that this did not entirely suit my personality profile.
Our team had five members who were all delegated with a particular role within the project.
In hindsight, this was one of the biggest challenges I faced in this activity. However, it also allowed me to build my skills and confidence in these areas, which will benefit me in future teamwork

For me, perhaps the most challenging part of being assigned this role was working and communicating effectively with our team in a clear and assertive way. Occasionally, I felt uneasy negotiating with other team members who I felt had their ‘own agenda’ and seemed unwilling at times to compromise.
data.stimulus:
TASK 5: Organising Reflective Writing

In the following questions, you will see mixed-up sentences from a piece of student reflective writing. Put the sentences in order to form logical structured paragraphs.

 

PARAGRAPH ONE:

list: For me, this was a significant handicap in our team and perhaps upon reflection I should have thought about how to allocate tasks in a more effective manner from the beginning.
Ellis (2012) argues that allocating tasks effectively can offer significant time savings when working in a group, so this is a skill I need to develop.
I will now reflect upon some of the challenges that our team faced, and how we could resolve them.
Effectively allocating tasks and meeting deadlines were two issues we faced. It was often hard to allocate tasks to team members due to conflicting schedules, workloads and other commitments.
Perhaps in future I could plan task allocation more carefully, taking into account the particular strengths or weaknesses of the individuals in my team.

data.stimulus: Do you understand how theory can be added to reflective writing?
